subject: OpenPOWER: Serialization of system dump
commitMessage:
OpenPOWER: Serialization of system dump

Change:
-Adding serialize and deserialize method to persist the D-Bus object
for system dump.

Test:
-Triggered a system dump, stopped the dump manager service and restarted
it. Able to see the entry for the dump created earlier.
Entry was seen using below command
busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Manager

Signed-off-by: Chirag Sharma <chirshar@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I3c5bae4516bf8658d155e42cd73104c9d9d5290e

It will be helpful if we have added information about cereal which is used to achieve serialization and deserialization.
Did you checked the properties value as well right?
serialize should be done here too

Why we can not move this serialization inside the constructor?

I know a few cases, we won't have properties value and these get updated as part of the "update" call. But, cereal won't allow serialization multiple times in the same file path?

IMO, forcing the caller to do serialization is not a good idea if we have some common functions like constructor and update.
Can't move this inside constructor, because in that case serialize will also be called in restore method.
Looks you are using the newly created constructor for restore right?
yes, but why to call it in constructor?
IMO more readable and maintainable if used constructor and update function for the serialization but, I will leave it to you.
even thogh readable it is not logical to do serialize in the constructor as we use the same constructor during restore. we cannot have one constructor for creation and another for restore.
I would prefer keeping it here instead of calling this in constructor.

JS: Actually, we could use the existing entries map itself, to find the highest id value by using the comparator lambda with std::max_element once you created the entries for all the dumps.

or Just we could have one variable `lastMaxEntryId` instead of vector.
There also we need to iterate(i.e. using map), thats why using vector as its easy.
Agree but, we can use the existing map itself instead of a new vector. I will leave it to you, logic seems correct and not a blocker comment, just a suggestion comment.

JS: We could do like below.
```
auto objPath = std::filesystem::path(baseEntryPath) / file.path().filename().string();
```

I think we should take care of the D-Bus signal because, you are emitting the signal once Entry object construction was done but, you did not populate all properties value, and these properties were updated during the deserialization.

Some other apps may use the D-Bus property watch signal so, it will get an inaccurate signal i.e after LN152 but, an actual property update happening at LN153.

Sorry unable to get this comment. 
We are restoring properties in deserial method i.e. LN153.

Sorry for the confusion.

I think you are emitting the D-Bus object creation signal in the above object constructor but, you are deserializing properties later and not emitting the signal for property value change so the watcher doesn't know it right?

In the restore path, if we want to emit the signal then we need to emit after the properties deserialization right?

are we emitting signals twice?

Looks, we are emitting signals in the constructor as well so it won't harm anything on the application side (who subscripted the signal)?
Do we not need to capture the trace if failed to restore it?
It will be good if you added the note to mention "other dbus properties values should be populated by the caller with help of the "update" function else default value only will be present".
basically this we use while restoring the entries.
Why we cannot define this member into the base entry class? - it is only needed for the system dump?

I got it, it is needed here but, checking whether we can add in the base entry itself?

For me, it looks like a common member for all types of dump, and even you added in the resource dump serialization patch (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/47234/1/dump-extensions/openpower-dumps/resource_dump_entry.hpp#11)
not all type of dump, added only for resource and system
Now it might not be needed but, adding it into the base class helps other types as well in the future. I will leave it to you and if somebody needs this need to move.
As of now keeping it as it is, can't touch dump_entry.hpp

Do we need to add the dependency check?
I think, cereal is a header-only-based library.

FYI, It is needed but it is already added
FYR: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/commit/abbe15932f4d20f681969afb2296a8b2832ce933
I believe, LN33 and LN54 (save and load) should be in sync, right? like order? if so can add some comment on this if make sense to you.

Why you are skipping the signal to emit for the property?

I think some bmc components will look for the property value change signal, right? One example is, bmcweb will watch for the status property value change to take the appropriate action.
load is at the time of restoring, we dont need to emit signal at that time.
But, you are emitting the D-Bus object creation signal right?
emitting signal after restoring the dumps.
discussed and no need to emit signal during signal.

Looks, you removed the emit signal https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/47088/9..10/dump-extensions/openpower-dumps/dump_manager_system.cpp

Please refer https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/6a83328d-c9d8-e387-6647-0595b9e73e88@linux.vnet.ibm.com/t/#openbmc-users mail thread and make sure your restore path meets that condition. please test add the test case on this.

i.e bmcweb should not get signal but, Mapper should get it to update their cache.
Made changes as suggested in the email registering the service after restoring the dumps, need to test it, Meanwhile will raise it for review.
Done. Can see the entries in the Mapper post restore and no signal emitted during restore.
Thanks, It will be good if you added the test details on this
Why you did not skip the signal to emit for size property?
This is not a dbus property.
is it error dbus object or dump dbus object?
is it error object or dump object? or What you meant by "error object"?
Who you meant as a "Caller"? Who trying to create the Entry object instance?

These functions will throw the exception, I think we should handle it else we will lose all dumps to restore if anyone is failed.

Since we are using the stored file so it might be a chance to corrupt/change the file name by someone better let's handle it because we need to restore how much we can.

I agree with you since you are calling inside the system namespace so it will look inner to the outer scope.

IMO we could add as "system::Enntry" for more readability like a few places you added as "system::Entry".
this should be system::Entry right not the base entry

Same as LN 190 comment.
I think you can add one try and catch block.
Looks you missed to address here.
Add the id/file path that will help us to debug.

I think you are using this constructor for the restore function so the D-Bus signal emission is required here?

In the restore path, if we want to emit the signal then we need to emit after the properties deserialization right?

/var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/system data is persist across BMC boot , since this is Hostdumps, whicg is stored in host memory , do need to restore after host poweroff. you shoul add  logic to clear this file as part entry delete and  host power-off path path to make sure not resoring this aftre power -off , BMC reboot -> hot boot path .
Will create a service file to delete the entries during poweroff.
Can you point the commit , whuich includes the service file changes.
Don't have the commit id. Will update once have it. Also will make sure both the changes i.e. service file and serialization gets merged together.
Please capture exceptions in the trace so it will help us during debug.
I think we should do serialization after insert? (very rare case, if insertion failed then, we won't have dbus objects but, we will have an entry in the persisted dump file.

as the entry is moved we will not have it any more for serialize, the chances of insert failing is like when system is out of memory by which every thing else will fail, we need not think so much about such minor things.
probably because the pointer will be lost after insert, i guess we are safe here
Do we need to add any info trace?
yeah some trace stating nothing to restore, will be helpful

Do you want to move forward or want to continue with the next dump file?

Please add some comments on this.
need to look at next file
Yes need to continue to retrieve the next dump.
Looks scope is inside try block, I am missing something?
Please update issue #2597 with gerrit link details.
Please add some more details like path and in which case we got exception so it helps during debug.
can we avoid touching this file, the requirement is only for IBM specific dumps
I hope it is tested if so I am good.
JS: you could add some details "System dump does not exist in the path [{}] to restore"

Looks like we are emitting object creation signal twice, please add some default argument to the system::Entry constructor and by default emit the signal but, we no need to emit the signal in the restore path.
JS, it will be good if you added the file name in the trace
JS, it will be good if you added the file name in the trace
Should be creating elog here. this is triggering dump service crash.
System Dump serial path. not dump directory.
This is an error scenario, Better to get error logged here.  Journal log life time is limited .
As per discussion, not adding errorlog
This is an error scenario, Better to get error logged here.
As per discussion, not adding errorlog
This is an error scenario, Better to get error logged here.
As per discussion, not adding errorlog
/var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/prserve/<system> . Thisway in future you can keep all presverved path in a common location.
